Authors:
Claudia Riccioni, Francesco Paolocci, Rodham E. Tulloss,
Claudia Perini
Title:
Molecular phylogenetic analyses show that Amanita ovoidea and
Amanita proxima are distinct species and suggest their assignment to
Amanita section Lepidella
Keywords:
Amanita aminoaliphatica, hybridization, internal
transcribed spacer, Mediterranean fungi, rpb2 gene, section
Amidella
Abstract:
Amanita ovoidea is generally considered edible and is
morphologically similar to Amanita proxima that contains nephrotoxins.
Both species have been assigned to Amanita [subgenus Lepidella] section
Amidella. To study phylogenetic relationships of A. ovoidea and A.
proxima, we performed the first nrITS- and rpb2- based analyses of these
and other Amanita spp. Our analyses show that: i) A. ovoidea and A.
proxima are distinct species; ii) A. ovoidea has an extensively
heterogenous ITS with up to 4.4% pairwise genetic distance between
individuals; iii) in A. ovoidea pairwise genetic distance between ITS
clones from a single basidiome was as high as 3.2%, possibly because of
hybridization events and subsequent failure of the rDNA repeats to
homogenize; iv) A. aminoaliphatica and A. proxima are taxonomic
synonyms; v) A. proxima, A. ovoidea and the related East Asian species
Amanita neoovoidea cluster with species belonging to section Lepidella
rather than with the species of section Amidella sensu stricto. This
study supports development of species-specific markers for diagnosis of
toxic, white amanitas.
